Corollary 2.3.3 For all $\alpha \geq 0$, and all $x \in \mathbb{R}^{n}, B_{\boxplus}(x, \alpha]$ is idempotent symmetric convex.
Proof: From Proposition 2.3.1, $B_{\boxplus}(x, \alpha]$ is the cartesian product between a box and a singleton. Since any box is idempotent symmetric convex, the result immediately follows.

In [8] the following formulation of a $\mathbb{B}$-polytope was established in the case of two points. ${ }^{4}$ For all $x, y \in \mathbb{R}^{n}$,

$$
C o^{\infty}(x, y)=\{t x \boxplus r x \boxplus s y \boxplus w y: \max \{t, r, s, w\}=1, t, r, s, w \geq 0\}
$$

In classical convexity, counting the same point twice in a finite set does not alter its convex hull. However, this is not the case here due to the specific properties of the non-associative operation we consider. This formulation is useful to prove the next decomposition result over $\left(\mathbb{R}^{n}, \boxplus, \cdot\right)$.

Proposition 2.3.4 For all $x, y \in \mathbb{R}^{n}$, and all $z \in C o^{\infty}(x, y)$ we have:

$$
d_{\boxplus}(x, y)=\max \left\{d_{\boxplus}(x, z), d_{\boxplus}(z, y)\right\}
$$

Proof: If $x=y$, then the result is immediate. Let us assume that $x \neq y$. Suppose that $z \in C o^{\infty}(x, y)$, in such a case there are some $r, s, t, w \in[0,1]$ with $\max \{r, s, t, w\}=1$ such that

$$
z=r x \boxplus s x \boxplus t y \boxplus w y
$$

Suppose that $\alpha=d_{\boxplus}(x, y)$. Let $\mathcal{L}(x, y)=\left\{i \in[n]: x_{i} \neq y_{i}\right\}$. By construction

$$
d_{\boxplus}(x, y)=\max \left\{\left|x_{i}\right|,\left|y_{i}\right|: i \in \mathcal{L}(x, y)\right\}
$$

Therefore, for all $i \notin \mathcal{L}(x, y)$, if $\left|x_{i}\right|>d_{\boxplus}(x, y)$ then $x_{i}=y_{i}$. Thus, we deduce that $z_{i}=r x_{i} \boxplus s x_{i} \boxplus t y_{i} \boxplus w y_{i}=$ $x_{i}=y_{i}$. It follows that $x_{i} \boxminus z_{i}=y_{i} \boxminus z_{i}=0$. Hence, we have:

$$
d_{\boxplus}(x, z)=\max \left\{\left|x_{i} \boxminus z_{i}\right|: i \in \mathcal{L}(x, y)\right\}
$$

and

$$
d_{\boxplus}(y, z)=\max \left\{\left|y_{i} \boxminus z_{i}\right|: i \in \mathcal{L}(x, y)\right\}
$$

Now, notice that for all $i$

$$
\left|z_{i}\right|=\left|r x_{i} \boxplus s x_{i} \boxplus t y_{i} \boxplus w y_{i}\right| \leq \max \left\{\left|x_{i}\right|,\left|y_{i}\right|\right\}
$$

[^0]
[^0]:    ${ }^{4}$ We use the convention that for all $(\alpha, \beta, \gamma, \delta) \in \mathbb{R}^{4}, \alpha \boxplus \beta \boxplus \gamma \boxplus \delta=\digamma_{[4]}(\alpha, \beta, \gamma, \delta)$.

Since, for all $i,\left|x_{i} \boxminus z_{i}\right| \leq \max \left\{\left|x_{i}\right|,\left|y_{i}\right|\right\}$ and $\left|y_{i} \boxminus z_{i}\right| \leq \max \left\{\left|x_{i}\right|,\left|y_{i}\right|\right\}$, we deduce that

$$
d_{\boxplus}(x, z) \leq \max \left\{\left|x_{i}\right|,\left|y_{i}\right|: i \in \mathcal{L}(x, y)\right\}=d_{\boxplus}(x, y)
$$

and

$$
d_{\boxplus}(y, z) \leq \max \left\{\left|x_{i}\right|,\left|y_{i}\right|: i \in \mathcal{L}(x, y)\right\}=d_{\boxplus}(x, y)
$$

Thus

$$
\max \left\{d_{\boxplus}(x, z), d_{\boxplus}(z, y)\right\} \leq d_{\boxplus}(x, y)
$$

However, from the triangular inequality, we have

$$
d_{\boxplus}(x, y) \leq \max \left\{d_{\boxplus}(x, z), d_{\boxplus}(z, y)\right\}
$$

Since the converse inequality holds, this completes the proof.
The next result is an immediate consequence.
Proposition 2.3.5 Let $A=\left\{x^{(1)}, \ldots, x^{(m)}\right\}$ be a finite subset of $\mathbb{R}^{n}$. Suppose moreover that $(i) C o^{\infty}\left(x^{(1)}, x^{(m)}\right)=$ $\bigcup_{i \in[m-1]} C o^{\infty}\left(x^{(i)}, x^{(i+1)}\right) ;$ (ii) for all $i C o^{\infty}\left(x^{(i-1)}, x^{(i)}\right) \cap C o^{\infty}\left(x^{(i)}, x^{(i+1)}\right)=\left\{x^{(i)}\right\}$. Then we have:

$$
d_{\boxplus}\left(x^{(1)}, x^{(m)}\right)=\max _{i \in[m-1]} d_{\boxplus}\left(x^{(i)}, x^{(i+1)}\right)
$$

Proof: Since $x^{(2)} \in C o^{\infty}\left(x^{(1)}, x^{(m)}\right)$, we have:

$$
d_{\boxplus}\left(x^{(1)}, x^{(m)}\right)=\max \left\{d_{\boxplus}\left(x^{(1)}, x^{(2)}\right), d_{\boxplus}\left(x^{(2)}, x^{(m)}\right)\right)\}
$$

From the decomposition property established in [10], we have $C o^{\infty}\left(x^{(k)}, x^{(m)}\right)=C o^{\infty}\left(x^{(k)}, x^{(k+1)}\right) \cup$ $C o^{\infty}\left(x^{(k+1)}, x^{(m)}\right)$. It follows that for any $k \in[m-1], x^{(k+1)} \in C o^{\infty}\left(x^{(k)}, x^{(m)}\right)$. Hence:

$$
d_{\boxplus}\left(x^{(k)}, x^{(m)}\right)=\max \left\{d_{\boxplus}\left(x^{(k)}, x^{(k+1)}\right), d_{\boxplus}\left(x^{(k+1)}, x^{(m)}\right)\right\}
$$

By recurrence the proof is then immediate.

Proposition 2.3.6 Let $x, y \in \mathbb{R}^{n}$. If $x=-y$, then for all $z \in C o^{\infty}(x, y) \backslash\{x, y\}, d_{\boxplus}(x, y)=d_{\boxplus}(x, z)=$ $d_{\boxplus}(z, y)$.

Proof: Suppose that $z \in C o^{\infty}(x, y)$, in such a case there are some $r, s, t, w \in[0,1]$ with $\max \{r, s, t, w\}=1$ such that $z=r x \boxplus s x \boxplus t y \boxplus w y$. Since $z \notin\{x, y\}$ we have $\max \{r, s\}=\max \{t, w\}=1$, and $\min \{r, s\}=$ $\max \{t, w\}=1$, otherwise either $z=x$ or $z=y$. If $r=s=t=w=1$, then $z=0$ and the result is immediate. Consequently $\max \{r, s\}=\max \{t, w\}=1, \min \{r, s\}<1$ and $\min \{t, w\}<1$. Dropping the symmetric terms, it follows that

$$
z=r x \boxplus s x \boxplus t y \boxplus w y=\min \{r, s\} x \boxplus \min \{t, w\} y
$$

Since $\min \{r, s\}<1$ and $\min \{t, w\}<1$, this implies that $d_{\boxplus}(x, y)=d_{\boxplus}(x, z)=d_{\boxplus}(z, y)$.

# 3 Some Trigonometric Properties in Limit 

In this section, we show that certain properties related to the notion of orthogonality can be derived within the framework of the idempotent and symmetric algebraic structure we consider.

# 3.1 Orthogonality and Pythagorean Properties in Limit 

In the following, for all $p \in \mathbb{N}$, we say that $x, y \in \mathbb{R}^{n}$ are $\varphi_{p}$-orthogonal if:

$$
\langle x, y\rangle_{p}=0
$$

In addition, we say that $x, y \in \mathbb{R}^{n}$ are $\digamma$-orthogonal if:

$$
\langle x, y\rangle_{\infty}=0
$$

In the sequel, the earlier results are extended to the general case of a triple $[x, y, z]$ of $\mathbb{R}^{n}$. Notice that we have for all natural numbers $p$

$$
\left\langle x \stackrel{p}{-} z, y \stackrel{p}{-} z\right\rangle_{p}=\sum_{i \in[n]}^{\varphi_{p}} x_{i} y_{i} \stackrel{p}{+} \sum_{i \in[n]}^{\varphi_{p}}\left(-x_{i} z_{i}\right) \stackrel{p}{+} \sum_{i \in[n]}^{\varphi_{p}}\left(-y_{i} z_{i}\right) \stackrel{p}{+} \sum_{i \in[n]}^{\varphi_{p}} z_{i}{ }^{2}
$$

Therefore:

$$
\lim _{p \longrightarrow \infty}\left\langle x \stackrel{p}{-} z, y \stackrel{p}{-} z\right\rangle_{p}=\digamma_{[4 n]}\left(x_{1} y_{1}, \ldots, x_{n} y_{n},-x_{1} z_{1}, \ldots,-x_{n} z_{n},-y_{1} z_{1}, \ldots,-y_{n} z_{n}, z_{1}{ }^{2}, \ldots, z_{n}{ }^{2}\right)
$$

In the following, we introduce the operation $\langle\langle\cdot, \cdot, \cdot\rangle_{\boxplus}: \mathbb{R}^{n} \times \mathbb{R}^{n} \times \mathbb{R}^{n} \longrightarrow \mathbb{R}$ defined as:

$$
\langle\langle x, y, z\rangle\rangle_{\infty}=\lim _{p \longrightarrow \infty}\left\langle x \stackrel{p}{-} z, y \stackrel{p}{-} z\right\rangle_{p}
$$

In the following, for all $x, y, z \in \mathbb{R}^{n}$, we say that $[x, y, z]$ is $\digamma$-right-angled in $z$ if

$$
\langle\langle x, y, z\rangle\rangle_{\infty}=0
$$

In general, a right-angled triangle is not a $\digamma$-right-angled triple. This is shown in the next example.
Example 3.1.1 Let $x=(1,-2,-1), y=(2,3,-2)$ and $z=(3,2,-3)$. We have $x-z=(-2,-4,2)$ and $y-z=(-1,1,1)$. We have $\langle x-z, y-z\rangle=0$. Therefore $[x, y, z]$ is a right-angled triangle. However $\digamma_{[12]}(2,-6,2,3,2,-3,-6,-6,-6,9,4,9)=9 \neq 0$. Hence $[x, y, z]$ is not a $\digamma$-right-angled triple.
The next result was established in [10]. It plays an important role in the remainder. It means that if the limit sum is zero then the $\phi_{p}$-generalized sum is zero for any $p$.
Lemma 3.1.2 Suppose that there is some $x=\left(x_{1}, \ldots, x_{n}\right) \in \mathbb{R}^{n}$ such that $\bigsqcup_{i \in[n]} x_{i}=0$. Then for all $p \in \mathbb{N}, \sum_{i \in[n]}^{\varphi_{p}} x_{i}=0$.

Proposition 3.1.3 Let $x, y, z \in \mathbb{R}^{n}$, and let $[x, y, z]$ be a triple. The triple $[x, y, z]$ is $\digamma$-right-angled in $z$ all if and only if for all $p \in \mathbb{N},[x, y, z]$ is $\varphi_{p}$-right-angled in $z$, i.e. $\left\langle x \stackrel{p}{-} z, y \stackrel{p}{-} z\right\rangle_{p}=0$.

Proof: If $[x, y, z]$ is a $\digamma$-right-angled triple in $z$ then:

$$
\langle\langle x, y, z\rangle\rangle_{\infty}=0
$$

It follows that

$$
\left\langle x \stackrel{p}{-} z, y \stackrel{p}{-} z\right\rangle_{p}=0
$$

for all $p \in \mathbb{N}$ and the first implication follows.
Conversely if for all $p,[x, y, z]$ is a $\varphi_{p}$-right-angled triple in $z$, then for all $p$

$$
\left\langle x \stackrel{p}{-} z, y \stackrel{p}{-} z\right\rangle_{p}=0
$$

Hence

$$
\lim _{p \longrightarrow \infty}\left\langle x \stackrel{p}{-} z, y \stackrel{p}{-} z\right\rangle_{p}=\langle\langle x, y, z\rangle\rangle_{\infty}=0
$$

which proves the reciprocal.

![img-3.jpeg](img-3.jpeg)

Fig. 4: $\digamma$-right-angled triples with convex lines.
![img-4.jpeg](img-4.jpeg)

Fig. 5: $\digamma$-right-angled triples with idempotent symmetric convex lines.

Remark 3.1.4 A $\digamma$-right-angled triple is a right-angled triangle. However, the converse is not true. In Figure $4,[a, b, c]$ is right-angled but not $\digamma$-right-angled. The triples $[d, f, e]$ and $[g, 0, h]$ are $\digamma$-right-angled.

In Figure 5, the same triples are represented using idempotent symmetric convex lines. Clearly, the right angle is preserved only for the triples $[d, f, e]$ and $[g, 0, h]$.

In the following, for all subsets $I$ of $[n]$ and all $x \in \mathbb{R}^{n}$, let us denote $x_{[I]}=\sum_{i \in I} x_{i} e_{i}$, where $\left\{e_{1}, \ldots, e_{n}\right\}$ is the canonic basis of $\mathbb{R}^{n}$.

Proposition 3.1.5 Let $x, y, z \in \mathbb{R}^{n}$, and let $[x, y, 0]$ is a $\digamma$-right-angled triple in 0 . Then there exists a partition $\left\{I_{1}, \ldots, I_{m}, J\right\}$ of $[n]$ with $m=\left\lfloor\frac{n}{2}\right\rfloor$, Card $(J) \in\{0,1\}$ and such that for all $k$ :

$$
\left[x_{\left[I_{k}\right]}, y_{\left[I_{k}\right]}, 0_{\left[I_{k}\right]}\right]
$$

is a right-angled triangle in $0_{\left[I_{k}\right]}$ of $\mathbb{R}^{I_{k}}$ with $\operatorname{Card}\left(I_{k}\right)=2$. Moreover, if $J=\{j\}$ is nonempty then $x_{j} y_{j}=0$.
Proof: If $[x, y, 0]$ is a $\digamma$-right-angled triple in 0 then:

$$
\bigoplus_{i \in[n]} x_{i} y_{i}=0
$$

$\bigsqcup_{i \in[n]} x_{i} y_{i}=0$ implies that there exists a partition $\left\{I_{1}, \ldots, I_{m}, J\right\}$ of $[n]$ with $m=\left\lfloor\frac{n}{2}\right\rfloor$, Card $\left(I_{k}\right)=2$ for all $k$ and $\operatorname{Card}(J) \in\{0,1\}$ such that:

$$
\sum_{i \in\left[I_{k}\right]} x_{i} y_{i}=\bigoplus_{i \in\left[I_{k}\right]} x_{i} y_{i}=0
$$

and $x_{j} y_{j}=0$ if $J=\{j\}$ is a nonempty set. Consequently

$$
\sum_{i \in\left[I_{k}\right]} x_{i} y_{i}=0
$$

Suppose that $I_{k}=\left\{i^{\prime}, i^{\prime \prime}\right\}$. Then

$$
x_{i^{\prime}} y_{i^{\prime}} \boxminus x_{i^{\prime \prime}} y_{i^{\prime \prime}}=0 \Longleftrightarrow x_{i^{\prime}} y_{i^{\prime}}-x_{i^{\prime \prime}} y_{i^{\prime \prime}}=0
$$

It follows that $\left\langle x_{\left[I_{k}\right]}, y_{\left[I_{k}\right]}\right\rangle_{p}=0$ for all $p$.
Corollary 3.1.6 Suppose that $n=2$. If $[x, y, 0]$ is a right-angled triangle in $z$ of $\mathbb{R}^{2}$, then $[x, y, 0]$ is $\digamma$ -right-angled in 0 and it is $\varphi_{p}$-right-angled in 0 for all natural numbers $p$.

The following result is an idempotent and non-associative analogue of the Pythagorean theorem.

Proposition 3.1.7 Let $x, y, z \in \mathbb{R}^{n}$, and let $[x, y, z]$ is a $\digamma$-right-angled triple in $z$. Then for all $p \in \mathbb{N}$ :

$$
d_{\varphi_{p}}^{2}(x, y)=d_{\varphi_{p}}^{2}(x, z) \stackrel{p}{+} d_{\varphi_{p}}^{2}(y, z)
$$

and

$$
d_{\boxplus}(x, y)=\max \left\{d_{\boxplus}(x, z), d_{\boxplus}(y, z)\right\}
$$

Proof: If $[x, y, z]$ is a $\digamma$-right-angled triple in $z$ then

$$
\left\langle\langle x, y, z\rangle\right\rangle_{\infty}=0
$$

Thus, for all $p,\left\langle x \stackrel{p}{-} z, y \stackrel{p}{-} z\right\rangle_{p}=0$. It follows that

$$
\left\langle\phi_{p}(x)-\phi_{p}(z), \phi_{p}(y)-\phi_{p}(z)\right\rangle=0
$$

Hence

$$
\left\|\phi_{p}(x)-\phi_{p}(y)\right\|^{2}=\left\|\phi_{p}(x)-\phi_{p}(z)\right\|^{2}+\left\|\phi_{p}(y)-\phi_{p}(z)\right\|^{2}
$$

We deduce that

$$
\left\|\phi_{p}\left(\phi_{p}^{-1}\left(\phi_{p}(x)-\phi_{p}(y)\right)\right)\right\|^{2}=\varphi_{p}\left(\varphi_{p}^{-1}\left(\left\|\phi_{p}\left(\phi_{p}^{-1}\left(\phi_{p}(x)-\phi_{p}(z)\right)\right)\right\|^{2}\right)\right)+\varphi_{p}\left(\varphi_{p}^{-1}\left(\left\|\phi_{p}\left(\phi_{p}^{-1}\left(\phi_{p}(y)-\phi_{p}(z)\right)\right)\right\|^{2}\right)\right)
$$

Thus:

$$
d_{\varphi_{p}}^{2}(x, y)=\left\|x \stackrel{p}{-} y\right\|_{\varphi_{p}}^{2}=\left\|x \stackrel{p}{-} z\right\|_{\varphi_{p}} \stackrel{p}{+}\left\|y \stackrel{p}{-} z\right\|_{\varphi_{p}}=d_{\varphi_{p}}^{2}(x, z) \stackrel{p}{+} d_{\varphi_{p}}^{2}(y, z)
$$

Taking the limit, yields:

$$
d_{\boxplus}^{2}(x, y)=\lim _{p \longrightarrow \infty} d_{\varphi_{p}}^{2}(x, y)=\lim _{p \longrightarrow \infty} d_{\varphi_{p}}^{2}(x, z) \stackrel{p}{+} d_{\varphi_{p}}^{2}(y, z)=\max \left\{d_{\boxplus}^{2}(x, z), d_{\boxplus}^{2}(y, z)\right\}
$$

The final statement immediately follows.

# 3.2 Cosine, Sine in Limit and some Parametrization of the Unit Square 

The purpose of this section is to demonstrate that we can use the limiting properties of standard trigonometric concepts to derive analogues of well-known geometric properties within the framework of the non-associative algebra we are studying. Paralleling the usual definition of a cosine, let us define the $\varphi_{p}$-pseudo-cosine of the angle between two vectors as:

$$
\cos _{p}(x, y)=\frac{\langle x, y\rangle_{p}}{\|x\|_{\varphi_{p}}\|y\|_{\varphi_{p}}}
$$

Taking the limit, we define the pseudo $\digamma$-cosine as:

$$
\cos _{\infty}(x, y)=\frac{\langle x, y\rangle_{\infty}}{\|x\|_{\infty}\|y\|_{\infty}}
$$

It is now natural to define a sine function in limit. In [11] a $\varphi_{p}$ exterior product is defined for all $v_{1}, v_{2}, \ldots, v_{n} \in \mathbb{R}^{n}$ as:

$$
\left(v_{1} \stackrel{p}{\wedge} v_{2} \stackrel{p}{\wedge} \cdots \stackrel{p}{\wedge} v_{n}\right)=\left|v_{1}, v_{2}, \ldots, v_{n}\right|_{p}\left(e_{1} \wedge e_{2} \wedge \cdots \wedge e_{n}\right)
$$

where:

$$
\begin{aligned}
\left(v_{1} \stackrel{p}{\wedge} v_{2} \stackrel{p}{\wedge} \cdots \stackrel{p}{\wedge} v_{n}\right) & =\varphi_{p}^{-1}\left(\phi_{p}\left(v_{1}\right) \wedge \phi_{p}\left(v_{2}\right) \wedge \cdots \wedge \phi_{p}\left(v_{n}\right)\right) \\
& =\varphi_{p}^{-1}\left(\left|\phi_{p}\left(v_{1}\right), \phi_{p}\left(v_{2}\right), \ldots, \phi_{p}\left(v_{n}\right)\right|\right)\left(e_{1} \wedge e_{2} \wedge \cdots \wedge e_{n}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

Taking the limit yields:

$$
\left(v_{1} \stackrel{\infty}{\wedge} v_{2} \stackrel{\infty}{\wedge} \cdots \stackrel{\infty}{\wedge} v_{n}\right)=\left|v_{1}, v_{2}, \ldots, v_{n}\right|_{\infty}\left(e_{1} \stackrel{\infty}{\wedge} e_{2} \stackrel{\infty}{\wedge} \cdots \stackrel{\infty}{\wedge} e_{n}\right)
$$

In the case of two vectors the exterior product can be identified to the exterior product and the oriented area of the cross product can be interpreted as the positive area of the parallelogram having $x$ and $y$ as sides:

$$
x \wedge y=|x, y|=\|x\|\|y\| \sin (x, y)
$$

The $\varphi_{p}$-sine function for two vectors $x, y \in \mathbb{R}^{2}$ is defined as

$$
\sin _{p}(x, y)=\frac{|x, y|_{p}}{\|x\|_{\varphi_{p}}\|y\|_{\varphi_{p}}}=\frac{\varphi_{p}^{-1}\left(\varphi_{p}\left(x_{1}\right) \varphi_{p}\left(y_{2}\right)-\varphi_{p}\left(x_{2}\right) \varphi_{p}\left(y_{1}\right)\right)}{\|x\|_{\varphi_{p}}\|y\|_{\varphi_{p}}}
$$

Along this line, let us define

$$
\sin _{\infty}(x, y)=\frac{|x, y|_{\infty}}{\|x\|_{\infty}\|y\|_{\infty}}=\lim _{p \longrightarrow \infty} \sin _{p}(x, y)=\frac{x_{1} y_{2} \boxminus x_{2} y_{1}}{\max \left\{\left|x_{1}, x_{2}\right|\right\} \max \left\{\left|y_{1}, y_{2}\right|\right\}}
$$

Lemma 3.2.1 For all $x, y \in \mathbb{R}^{n}$, we have the following properties.
(a) $\cos _{p}(x, y)=\varphi_{p}^{-1}\left(\cos \left(\phi_{p}(x), \phi_{p}(y)\right)\right)$ and $\sin _{p}(x, y)=\varphi_{p}^{-1}\left(\sin \left(\phi_{p}(x), \phi_{p}(y)\right)\right)$.
(b) $\cos _{p}(x, y)^{2} \stackrel{p}{+} \sin _{p}(x, y)^{2}=1$.
(c) $\max \left\{\left|\cos _{\infty}(x, y)\right|,\left|\sin _{\infty}(x, y)\right|\right\}=1$.

Proof: (a) The first statement is immediate. To prove the second part note that:

$$
\sin _{p}(x, y)=\frac{|x, y|_{p}}{\|x\|_{\varphi_{p}}\|y\|_{\varphi_{p}}}=\frac{\varphi_{p}^{-1}\left(\left|\phi_{p}(x), \phi_{p}(y)\right|\right)}{\varphi_{p}^{-1}\left(\left\|\phi_{p}(x)\right\|\right) \varphi_{p}^{-1}\left(\left\|\phi_{p}(y)\right\|\right)}
$$

Therefore

$$
\sin _{p}(x, y)=\varphi_{p}^{-1}\left(\frac{\left|\phi_{p}(x), \phi_{p}(y)\right|}{\left\|\phi_{p}(x)\right\|\left\|\phi_{p}(y)\right\|}\right)=\varphi_{p}^{-1}\left(\sin \left(\phi_{p}(x), \phi_{p}(y)\right)\right)
$$

(b) We have

$$
\begin{aligned}
\cos _{p}(x, y)^{2} \stackrel{p}{+} \sin _{p}(x, y)^{2} & =\varphi_{p}\left(\left[\varphi_{p}^{-1}\left(\cos \left(\phi_{p}(x), \phi_{p}(y)\right)\right)\right]^{2}\right)+\varphi_{p}\left(\left[\varphi_{p}^{-1}\left(\sin \left(\phi_{p}(x), \phi_{p}(y)\right)\right)\right]^{2}\right) \\
& =\varphi_{p}\left(\varphi_{p}^{-1}\left[\left(\cos \left(\phi_{p}(x), \phi_{p}(y)\right)\right]^{2}\right)\right)+\varphi_{p}\left(\varphi_{p}^{-1}\left(\left[\sin \left(\phi_{p}(x), \phi_{p}(y)\right)\right]^{2}\right)\right) \\
& =\left(\cos \left(\phi_{p}(x), \phi_{p}(y)\right)\right)\right)^{2}+\left(\sin \left(\phi_{p}(x), \phi_{p}(y)\right)\right)^{2}=1
\end{aligned}
$$

(c) From (a) and (b), we have

$$
\max \left\{\left|\cos _{\infty}(x, y)\right|^{2},\left|\sin _{\infty}(x, y)\right|^{2}\right\}=\lim _{p \longrightarrow \infty} \cos _{p}(x, y)^{2} \stackrel{p}{+} \sin _{p}(x, y)^{2}=1
$$

Therefore,

$$
\max \left\{\left|\cos _{\infty}(x, y)\right|,\left|\sin _{\infty}(x, y)\right|\right\}=1
$$

Let $C_{\infty}(0,1]=\left\{\left(x_{1}, x_{2}\right) \in \mathbb{R}^{2}: \max \left\{\left|x_{1}\right|,\left|x_{2}\right|\right\}=1\right\}$ be the circle defined with respect to the $\left\|\|_{\infty}\right.$ metric in $\mathbb{R}^{2}$. Let us consider the points $a=(1,0), b=(1,1), c=(0,1), d=(-1,1), e=(-1,0), f=(-1,-1)$, $g=(0,-1), h=(1,-1)$. By construction:

$$
C_{\infty}(0,1]=C_{\mathbb{E}}(0,1]=[a, b] \cup[b, d] \cup[d, f] \cup[f, h] \cup[h, a]
$$

![img-5.jpeg](img-5.jpeg)

Fig. 6: Pseudo Cosine.

In the following we will identify the angles of the square with the length of the segments of its circumference. Let us consider the map $\alpha: C_{\infty}(0,1] \longrightarrow[0,8]$ defined by:

$$
\alpha\left(x_{1}, x_{2}\right)=\left\{\begin{array}{ccc}
x_{2} & \text { if } & x \in[a, b] \\
2-x_{1} & \text { if } & x \in[b, d] \\
4-x_{2} & \text { if } & x \in[d, f] \\
6+x_{1} & \text { if } & x \in[f, h] \\
8+x_{2} & \text { if } & x \in[h, a]
\end{array}\right.
$$

Clearly, we have $\alpha(a)=0, \alpha(b)=1, \alpha(c)=2, \alpha(d)=3, \alpha(e)=4, \alpha(f)=5, \alpha(g)=6, \alpha(h)=7$.
It is easy to prove that this map is a bijection from $C_{\infty}(0,1]$ to $[0,8]$. Notice that 8 is the perimeter of $C_{\infty}(0,1]$. For all $\theta \in[0,8]$ we define the pseudo-cosine pcos : $\mathbb{R} \longrightarrow[-1,1]$ as a periodic function with period 8 :

$$
\operatorname{pcos}(\theta)=\cos _{\infty}\left(\alpha^{-1}(\theta), e_{1}\right) \quad \bmod 8
$$

It follows that for any integer $k \in \mathbb{Z}$

$$
\operatorname{pcos}(\theta+8 k)=\left\{\begin{array}{ccc}
1 & \text { if } & \theta \in[0,1] \\
2-\theta & \text { if } & \theta \in[1,3] \\
-1 & \text { if } & \theta \in[3,5] \\
-6+\theta & \text { if } & \theta \in[5,7] \\
1 & \text { if } & \theta \in[7,8]
\end{array}\right.
$$

![img-6.jpeg](img-6.jpeg)

Fig. 7: Pseudo Cosine Function
Parallel to the previous definition, for all $\theta \in[0,8]$, we define the pseudo-sine function $\operatorname{psin}: \mathbb{R} \longrightarrow[-1,1]$ as a periodic function with period 8 :

$$
\operatorname{psin}(\theta)=\sin _{\infty}\left(\alpha^{-1}(\theta), e_{1}\right) \quad \bmod 8
$$

It follows that for any integer $z \in \mathbb{Z}$

$$
\operatorname{psin}(\theta+8 k)= \begin{cases}\theta & \text { if } \quad \theta \in[0,1] \\ 1 & \text { if } \quad \theta \in[1,3] \\ 4-\theta & \text { if } \quad \theta \in[3,5] \\ -1 & \text { if } \quad \theta \in[5,7] \\ 8-\theta & \text { if } \quad \theta \in[7,8]\end{cases}
$$

Hence, for all $\theta \in \mathbb{R}$, we have from Lemma 3.2.1

$$
\max \{|\operatorname{pcos}(\theta)|,|\operatorname{psin}(\theta)|\}=\max \left\{\left|\cos _{\infty}\left(\alpha^{-1}(\theta), e_{1}\right)\right|,\left|\sin _{\infty}\left(\alpha^{-1}(\theta), e_{1}\right)\right|\right\}=1
$$

# 3.3 Some Formalism on the Complex Scalar Field 

We can continue the previous analogies, this time using complex numbers and studying the relative properties of the unit square. Let us denote $C_{\varphi_{p}}(0,1]=\left\{x \in \mathbb{R}^{n}:\|x\|_{\varphi_{p}}=1\right\}$. We have the relations $\phi_{p}\left(C_{\varphi_{p}}(0,1]\right)=$ $C(0,1]$. Now, let us consider the subsets of $\mathbb{C}$ defined as $C_{\varphi_{p}}^{\natural}(0,1]=\{z=a+\mathrm{i} b \in \mathbb{C}:\|(a, b)\|_{\varphi_{p}}=1\}$ and $C_{\infty}^{\natural}(0,1]=\{z=a+\mathrm{i} b \in \mathbb{C}:\|(a, b)\|_{\infty}=1\}$. Let us consider the bijective map $\varphi^{\natural}: \mathbb{C} \longrightarrow \mathbb{C}$ defined as:

$$
\varphi_{p}^{\natural}(a+\mathrm{i} b)=\varphi_{p}(a)+\mathrm{i} \varphi_{p}(b)
$$

Its reciprocal is the map $\varphi^{\natural}{ }^{1}: \mathbb{C} \longrightarrow \mathbb{C}$ defined as $\varphi_{p}^{\natural}{ }^{1}(a+\mathrm{i} b)=\varphi_{p}^{-1}(a)+\mathrm{i} \varphi_{p}^{-1}(b)$. The map $\varphi_{p}^{\natural}$ is homogeneous with respect to the real scalar field, i.e. for all $\rho \in \mathbb{R}, \varphi_{p}^{\natural}(\rho(a+\mathrm{i} b))=\rho\left(\varphi_{p}(a)+\mathrm{i} \varphi_{p}(b)\right)=$ $\rho \varphi_{p}^{\natural}(a+\mathrm{i} b)$. Therefore, for all $z=\rho e^{\mathrm{i} \theta} \in \mathbb{C}$, with $\rho=|z|$, we have

$$
\varphi_{p}^{\natural}{ }^{1}(z)=\rho\left(\varphi_{p}^{-1}(\cos \theta)+\mathrm{i} \varphi_{p}^{-1}(\sin \theta)\right)
$$

For all $z, w \in \mathbb{C}^{2}$, let us define:

$$
z^{p} w=\varphi_{p}^{\natural}{ }^{1}\left(\varphi_{p}^{\natural}(z) \varphi_{p}^{\natural}(w)\right)
$$

It follows that if $z=a+\mathrm{i} b$ and $w=c+\mathrm{i} d$, then:

$$
z^{p} w=\varphi_{p}^{-1}\left(\varphi_{p}(a) \varphi_{p}(b)-\varphi_{p}(b) \varphi_{p}(d)\right)+\mathrm{i} \varphi_{p}^{-1}\left(\varphi_{p}(a) \varphi_{p}(c)+\varphi_{p}(b) \varphi_{p}(c)\right)
$$

Equivalently

$$
z^{p} w=\left(a b \stackrel{p}{-} b d\right)+\mathrm{i}\left(a d \stackrel{p}{+} b c\right)
$$

Along this line, taking the limit with respect to the product topology of $\mathbb{R}^{2}$, we define the product:

$$
z \boxtimes w=\lim _{p \rightarrow \infty} z^{p} w=(a b \boxminus b d)+\mathrm{i}(a d \boxplus b c)
$$

Note that this product is equivalent to the matrix product defined in [11] for matrices representing complex numbers. We have for all complex numbers of the form $z=a+\mathrm{i} b$ and $w=c+\mathrm{i} d$ :

$$
\left(\begin{array}{cc}
a & -b \\
b & a
\end{array}\right) \boxtimes\left(\begin{array}{cc}
c & -d \\
d & c
\end{array}\right)=\left(\begin{array}{cc}
a c \boxminus b d & -(a d \boxplus b c) \\
a d \boxplus b c & a c \boxminus b d
\end{array}\right)
$$

Moreover, for all $p \in \mathbb{N}$, and all $z=a+\mathrm{i} b \in \mathbb{C}$ we define the $\varphi_{p}$-module of $z$ as $|z|_{p}=\|(a, b)\|_{\varphi_{p}}$. Similarly, $|z|_{\infty}=\|(a, b)\|_{\infty}=\max \{|a|,|b|\}$. In the following, we also extend the operation $\boxplus$ to the complex numbers. For all $z=a+\mathrm{i} b$ and $w=c+\mathrm{i} d$, we have :

$$
z \boxplus w=(a \boxplus c)+\mathrm{i}(b \boxplus d)
$$

We can then establish the following relations.

Lemma 3.3.1 We have the following properties:
(a) For all $z \in \mathbb{C}$, there exists some $\theta \in[0,8]$ such that

$$
z=\|z\|_{\infty}(\operatorname{pcos}(\theta)+\mathrm{i} \operatorname{psin}(\theta))
$$

(b) If $z=a+\mathrm{i} b$ then $\sqrt{z \boxtimes \bar{z}}=\left.=|z|_{\infty}=\max \{|a|,|b|\}\right.$.
(c) If $z \neq 0$, then $z \cdot \frac{1}{|z|_{\infty}^{b}} \bar{z}=1$.
(d) Suppose that $z, w \in C_{\infty}^{\natural}(0,1]$, then $z \boxtimes w \in C_{\infty}^{\natural}(0,1]$.
(e) Suppose that $z, w \in \mathbb{C}$, then $|z \boxtimes w|_{\infty}=|z|_{\infty}|w|_{\infty}$.

Proof: (a) Suppose that $z=a+\mathrm{i} b$. If $z=0$, the result is trivial. If $z \neq 0$ then

$$
z=\max \{|a|,|b|\} \frac{a+\mathrm{i} b}{\max \{|a|,|b|\}}=\left.|z|_{\infty}\left(\frac{a}{\max \{|a|,|b|\}}+\mathrm{i} \frac{b}{\max \{|a|,|b|\}}\right)\right)
$$

However $\left(\frac{a}{\max \{|a|,|b|\}}+\mathrm{i} \frac{b}{\max \{|a|,|b|\}}\right) \in C_{\infty}^{\natural}(0,1]$. Hence there is some $\theta \in[0,8]$ such that

$$
\left(\frac{a}{\max \{|a|,|b|\}}+\mathrm{i} \frac{b}{\max \{|a|,|b|\}}\right)=\operatorname{pcos} \theta+\mathrm{i} \operatorname{psin} \theta
$$

Hence

$$
z=\|z\|_{\infty}(\operatorname{pcos}(\theta)+\mathrm{i} \operatorname{psin}(\theta))
$$

(b) We have $z \boxtimes \bar{z}=(a+\mathrm{i} b) \boxtimes(a-\mathrm{i} b)=\left(a^{2} \boxplus b^{2}\right)+\mathrm{i}(a b \boxminus a b)=a^{2} \boxplus b^{2}=\max \{|a|,|b|\}^{2}$ which yields the result. (c) is immediate from (b).
(d) Suppose that $z=a+\mathrm{i} b$ and $w=c+\mathrm{i} d$. We first assume that $z, w \in C_{\infty}^{\natural}(0,1]$. This implies that $\max \{|a|,|b|\}=\max \{|c|,|d|\}=1$. By definition we have:

$$
z \boxtimes w=(a c \boxminus b d)+\mathrm{i}(a d \boxplus b c)
$$

We need to prove that $\max \{|a c \boxminus b d|,|a d \boxplus b c|\}=1$. We consider the following cases:
$(i)$ if $|a|<1$ and $|c|<1$ then $|b d|=1$ and consequently $|a c \boxminus b d|=1$; (ii) if $|a|<1$ and $|d|<1$ then $|b c|=1$, therefore $|a d \boxplus b c|=1$; (iii) if $|c|<1$ and $|b|<1$ then $|a d|=1$ and we deduce that $|a d \boxplus b c|=1$; (iv) if $|b|<1$ and $|d|<1$ then $|a c|=1$, hence we have $|a c \boxminus b d|=1$.

Suppose now that $|a|=|b|=|c|=|d|=1$. All we need to show is that we cannot have $a c \boxminus b d=a d \boxplus b c=$ 0 . In such a case we have $a c=b d$ and $a d=-b c$. However, since $|c|=|d|=1$, this implies that $d^{2}=-c^{2}$ that is a contradiction. Consequently, we deduce that that if $z, w \in C_{\infty}^{\natural}(0,1]$ then $z \boxtimes w \in C_{\infty}^{\natural}(0,1]$.
(e) Suppose that $z=\left|z\right|_{\infty}(\operatorname{pcos}(\theta)+\mathrm{i} \operatorname{psin}(\theta))$ and $w=|w|_{\infty}(\operatorname{pcos}(\alpha)+\mathrm{i} \operatorname{psin}(\alpha))$. We have:

$$
z \boxtimes w=|z|_{\infty}|w|_{\infty}(\operatorname{pcos}(\theta) \operatorname{pcos}(\alpha) \boxminus \operatorname{psin}(\theta) \operatorname{psin}(\alpha)+\mathrm{i}(\operatorname{pcos}(\theta) \operatorname{psin}(\alpha) \boxplus \operatorname{psin}(\theta) \operatorname{pcos}(\alpha)))
$$

Hence, since

$$
|\operatorname{pcos}(\theta) \operatorname{pcos}(\alpha) \boxminus \operatorname{psin}(\theta) \operatorname{psin}(\alpha)+\mathrm{i}(\operatorname{pcos}(\theta) \operatorname{psin}(\alpha) \boxplus \operatorname{psin}(\theta) \operatorname{pcos}(\alpha))|_{\infty}=1
$$

we deduce the result.

# 4 Algebraic Formulation of the Kuratowski-Peano Limit of a Line
### 4.1 Algebraic Formulation of a Line

In this section, we demonstrate that the non-associative algebraic structure we consider allows for establishing an algebraic formulation of any limiting line passing through two points. In the standard convex case it is easy to give an algebraic formulation of a line passing trough two different points. In such a case one can define the line passing trough $x$ and $y(x \neq y)$ as:

$$
\mathcal{D}(x, y)=\{t x+s y: s+t=1, s, t \in \mathbb{R}\}
$$

Note that there is no restriction imposing the non-negativity of $s$ and $t$ which limits a line to a line-segment. Paralleling this definition one can define a $\varphi_{p}$-line as:

$$
\mathcal{D}^{(p)}(x, y)=\left\{t x \stackrel{p}{+} s y: s \stackrel{p}{+} t=1, s, t \in \mathbb{R}\right\}
$$

It was pointed out in [8] that the subset $\{t x \boxplus s y: \max \{s, t\}=1, s, t \geq 0\}$ is not path-connected and does not describe, over $\mathbb{R}^{n}$, the convex hull in the limit of $\{x, y\}$. To that end it was shown in [8] that $C o^{\infty}(x, y)=\{t x \boxplus r x \boxplus s y \boxplus w y: \max \{t, r, s, w\}=1, t, r, s, w \geq 0\}$. In what follows, we take a parallel approach to give the algebraic description of a line. Let us consider the following subset:

$$
\mathcal{D}^{\infty}(x, y):=\{t x \boxplus r x \boxplus s y \boxplus w y: t \boxplus r \boxplus s \boxplus w=1, t, r, s, w \in \mathbb{R}\}
$$

Lemma 4.1.1 For all $x, y \in \mathbb{R}^{n}$ with $x \neq y$,

$$
\mathcal{D}^{\infty}(x, y) \subset \underset{p \longrightarrow \infty}{\operatorname{Li}} \mathcal{D}^{(p)}(x, y)
$$

Proof: Suppose that $z \in\{t x \boxplus r x \boxplus s y \boxplus w y: t \boxplus r \boxplus s \boxplus w=1, t, r, s, w \in \mathbb{R}\}$. By definition, there exist $\alpha_{1}, \alpha_{2}, \beta_{1}, \beta_{2} \in \mathbb{R}$ with $\alpha_{1} \boxplus \alpha_{2} \boxplus \beta_{1} \boxplus \beta_{2}=1$ and such that

$$
z=\alpha_{1} x \boxplus \alpha_{2} x \boxplus \beta_{1} y \boxplus \beta_{2} y
$$

Since $\alpha_{1} \boxplus \alpha_{2} \boxplus \beta_{1} \boxplus \beta_{2}=1$, there exists some $p_{0} \in \mathbb{N}$ such that, for all $p \geq p_{0}, \alpha_{1} \stackrel{p}{+} \alpha_{2} \stackrel{p}{+} \beta_{1} \stackrel{p}{+} \beta_{2} \neq 0$. For all $p \geq p_{0}$, define

$$
z^{(p)}=\frac{1}{\alpha_{1} \stackrel{p}{+} \alpha_{2} \stackrel{p}{+} \beta_{1} \stackrel{p}{+} \beta_{2}}\left(\alpha_{1} x \stackrel{p}{+} \alpha_{2} x \stackrel{p}{+} \beta_{1} y \stackrel{p}{+} \beta_{2} y\right)
$$

By construction, for all $p \geq p_{0}, z^{(p)} \in \mathcal{D}^{(p)}(x, y)$. Taking the limit on both sides yields:

$$
\begin{aligned}
\lim _{p \longrightarrow \infty} z^{(p)} & =\frac{1}{\alpha_{1} \boxplus \alpha_{2} \boxplus \beta_{1} \boxplus \beta_{2}}\left(\alpha_{1} x \boxplus \alpha_{2} x \boxplus \beta_{1} y \boxplus \beta_{2} y\right) \\
& =\alpha_{1} x \boxplus \alpha_{2} x \boxplus \beta_{1} y \boxplus \beta_{2} y=z
\end{aligned}
$$

Consequently, $z \in \operatorname{Li}_{p \longrightarrow+\infty} \mathcal{D}^{(p)}(x, y)$.
Lemma 4.1.2 Let $\left\{\left(s^{(p)}, t^{(p)}\right)\right\}_{p \in \mathbb{N}}$ be sequence of $\mathbb{R}^{2}$. Suppose there is an increasing subsequence $\left\{p_{q}\right\}_{q \in \mathbb{N}}$ of natural numbers such that $s^{\left(p_{q}\right)} \stackrel{p_{q}}{+} t^{\left(p_{q}\right)}=1$ and $\lim _{q \longrightarrow \infty}\left(s^{\left(p_{q}\right)}, t^{\left(p_{q}\right)}\right)=(s, t)$. We have the following properties:
(a) If $\max \{|s|,|t|\}>1$ then $s=-t$.
(b) If $s=-t$ then $|s|=|t| \geq 1$.
(c) If $\min \{|s|,|t|\} \leq 1$ then $\max \{s, t\}=1$.
(d) If $s \neq-t$ then $\max \{s, t\}=1$.

Proof: (a) In such a case if $|s|>1$ then $t=\lim _{q \longrightarrow \infty} t_{p_{q}}=\lim _{q \longrightarrow \infty} 1 \stackrel{p_{q}}{ } s_{p_{q}}=-s$. The proof is symmetrical if $|t|>1$. (b) Let us prove that in such a case we have $|s| \geq 1$ and $|t| \geq 1$. If $|s|<1$ then $t=\lim _{q \longrightarrow \infty} t_{p_{q}}=$ $\lim _{q \longrightarrow \infty} 1 \stackrel{p_{q}}{ } s_{p_{q}}=1$, which contradicts $s=-t$. Similarly, if $|t|<1$ we have a contradiction. Therefore $|s| \geq 1$ and $|t| \geq 1$. (c) If $s=1$, then the conclusion is obvious. If $|s|<1$, then $t=\lim _{q \longrightarrow \infty} t_{p_{q}}=\lim _{q \longrightarrow \infty} 1 \stackrel{p_{q}}{ } s_{p_{q}}=1$ and $\max \{s, t\}=1$. To conclude if $s=-1$, then $t=\lim _{q \longrightarrow \infty} t_{p_{q}}=\lim _{q \longrightarrow \infty} 1 \stackrel{p_{q}}{ } 1=1$, which ends the proof of (c). (d) From $(a), s \neq-t$ implies that $\max \{|s|,|t|\} \leq 1$. Hence $\min \{|s|,|t|\} \leq 1$ and the result is then immediate from $(c)$.

The next lemma is a preliminary result to show the upper limit of the sequence $\left\{\mathcal{D}^{(p)}\right\}_{p \in \mathbb{N}}$ is identical to $\mathcal{D}^{\infty}$.

Lemma 4.1.3 Let $x, y \in \mathbb{R}^{n}$ with $x \neq y$ and suppose that $z \in \mathrm{~L} s_{p \longrightarrow \infty} \mathcal{D}^{(p)}(x, y)$. Then there exists a sequence $\left\{\left(s^{(p)}, t^{(p)}\right)\right\}_{p \in \mathbb{N}} \subset \mathbb{R}^{2}$ and an increasing subsequence $\left\{p_{q}\right\}_{q \in \mathbb{N}}$ of natural numbers such that $s^{\left(p_{q}\right) \stackrel{p_{q}}{+}} t^{\left(p_{q}\right)}=1, \lim _{q \longrightarrow \infty}\left(s^{\left(p_{q}\right)}, t^{\left(p_{q}\right)}\right)=(s, t)$ and

$$
z_{i}=s x_{i} \boxplus t y_{i}
$$

for all $i \in[n]$ such that $s x_{i} \neq-t y_{i}$.
Proof: Suppose that $z \in \mathrm{~L} s_{p \longrightarrow \infty} \mathcal{D}^{(p)}(x, y)$. In such a case there exists an increasing sequence of natural numbers $\left\{p_{k}\right\}_{k \in \mathbb{N}}$ and sequence $\left\{z^{\left(p_{k}\right)}\right\}_{k \in \mathbb{N}}$ with $z^{\left(p_{k}\right)} \in \mathcal{D}^{\left(p_{k}\right)}(x, y)$ for all $k$ and $\lim _{q \longrightarrow \infty} z^{\left(p_{k}\right)}=z$. This implies that there exists a sequence $\left\{s^{\left(p_{k}\right)}, t^{\left(p_{k}\right)}\right\}_{k \in \mathbb{N}} \subset \mathbb{R} \times \mathbb{R}$ such that

$$
z^{\left(p_{k}\right)}=t^{\left(p_{k}\right)} x \stackrel{p_{k}}{+} s^{\left(p_{k}\right)} y
$$

with $s^{\left(p_{k}\right)} \stackrel{p_{k}}{+} t^{\left(p_{k}\right)}=1$ for all $k$. Let us prove that $\left\{\left(s^{\left(p_{k}\right)}, t^{\left(p_{k}\right)}\right)\right\}_{q \in \mathbb{N}}$ is a bounded sequence. Suppose that this is not the case and let us show a contradiction. Suppose for example that $\left\{s^{\left(p_{k}\right)}\right\}_{k \in \mathbb{N}}$ is not bounded. An elementary calculus shows that since $t^{\left(p_{k}\right)}=1 \stackrel{p_{k}}{=} s^{\left(p_{k}\right)}$. Thus:

$$
z^{\left(p_{k}\right)}=x \stackrel{p_{k}}{+} s^{\left(p_{k}\right)}\left(y \stackrel{p_{k}}{=} x\right)
$$

However $\lim _{k \longrightarrow \infty} y^{p_{k}} x=y \boxminus x$. Since $x \neq y, y \boxminus x \neq 0$ and this implies that $\lim _{k \longrightarrow \infty}\left\|z^{\left(p_{q}\right)}\right\|=\infty$ that is a contradiction. Consequently $\left\{s^{\left(p_{k}\right)}\right\}_{k \in \mathbb{N}}$ is bounded. Since $s^{\left(p_{k}\right)}=1 \stackrel{p_{k}}{-} t^{\left(p_{k}\right)}$ this also implies that $\left\{t^{\left(p_{k}\right)}\right\}_{k \in \mathbb{N}}$ is bounded. Therefore, we deduce that the sequence $\left\{\left(s^{\left(p_{k}\right)}, t^{\left(p_{k}\right)}\right)\right\}_{k \in \mathbb{N}}$ is bounded. Consequently one can extract an increasing subsequence $\left\{p_{k_{m}}\right\}_{m \in \mathbb{N}}$ such that

$$
\lim _{m \longrightarrow \infty}\left(s^{\left(p_{k_{m}}\right)}, t^{\left(p_{k_{m}}\right)}\right)=(s, p)
$$

Let us denote $I=\left\{i \in[n]: s x_{i} \boxplus t y_{i}=0\right\}$. For all $i \notin I$, since $s x_{i} \neq-t y_{i}$ we have

$$
\lim _{m \longrightarrow \infty} s^{\left(p_{k_{m}}\right)} x_{i} \stackrel{p_{k_{m}}}{+} t^{\left(p_{k_{m}}\right)} y_{i}=s x_{i} \boxplus t y_{i}
$$

which yields the result.

Proposition 4.1.4 For all $x, y \in \mathbb{R}^{n}$ with $x \neq y$,

$$
\underset{p \longrightarrow \infty}{\operatorname{Lim}} \mathcal{D}^{(p)}(x, y)=\mathcal{D}^{\infty}(x, y)
$$

Proof: To prove this result, we need to establish that $\mathrm{L} s_{p \longrightarrow \infty} \mathcal{D}^{(p)}(x, y) \subset\left\{t x \boxplus r x \boxplus s y \boxplus w y: t \boxplus r \boxplus s \boxplus w=\right.$ $1, t, r, s, w \in \mathbb{R}\}$. Suppose that $z \in \mathrm{~L} s_{p \longrightarrow \infty} \mathcal{D}^{(p)}(x, y)$. By hypothesis, there exists an increasing sequence of natural numbers $\left\{p_{q}\right\}_{q \in \mathbb{N}}$ and sequence $\left\{z^{\left(p_{q}\right)}\right\}_{q \in \mathbb{N}}$ with $z^{\left(p_{q}\right)}=t^{\left(p_{q}\right)} x \stackrel{p_{q}}{+} s^{\left(p_{q}\right)} y \in \mathcal{D}^{\left(p_{q}\right)}(x, y)$ for all $q$ such that $\lim _{q \longrightarrow \infty} z^{\left(p_{q}\right)}=z$. Moreover, $\lim _{p \longrightarrow \infty}\left(s^{\left(p_{q}\right)}, t^{\left(p_{q}\right)}\right)=(s, p)$ and

$$
\lim _{p \longrightarrow \infty} s^{\left(p_{q}\right)} x_{i} \stackrel{p_{q}}{+} t^{\left(p_{q}\right)} y_{i}=s x_{i} \boxplus t y_{i}
$$

for all $i$ such that $s x_{i} \neq-t y_{i}$. Let $I=\left\{i \in[n]: s x_{i} \boxplus t y_{i}=0\right\}$. We consider three cases.
(a) $I=\emptyset$. If $\min \{|s|,|t|\}>1$ then, from Lemma 4.1.2.(a), $s=-t$. Let us consider the vector

$$
s x \boxplus x \boxplus(1-\epsilon) y \boxplus t y
$$

where $\epsilon>0$ is sufficiently small. Clearly, we have $s \boxplus 1 \boxplus(1-\epsilon) \boxplus t=1 \boxplus(1-\epsilon)=1$. Moreover, since $|s|=|t|>1$, for all $i \in[n]$ we have $s x_{i} \boxplus t y_{i}=s x_{i} \boxplus x_{i} \boxplus(1-\epsilon) y_{i} \boxplus t y_{i}$. From equation (1)

$$
z=s x \boxplus t y=s x \boxplus x \boxplus(1-\epsilon) y \boxplus t y
$$

Therefore $z \in \mathcal{D}^{\infty}(x, y)$. If $\min \{|s|,|t|\} \leq 1$ then, from Lemma 4.1.2, $\max \{s, t\}=1$. Suppose that $t=1$. Then, $s x \boxplus t y=s x \boxplus 0 x \boxplus y \boxplus y$ and $s \boxplus 0 \boxplus 1 \boxplus 1=1$. One can proceeds symmetrically if $s=1$.
(b) $I \neq \emptyset$ and for all $i \in I, x_{i}=y_{i}$. In such a case for all $i \in I, z_{i}^{\left(p_{q}\right)}=x_{i}=z_{i}$. For all $i \in I$, $s x_{i}=-t y_{i}=-t x_{i}$ and this implies that $s=-t$. From Lemma Lemma 4.1.2.(b) we have $|s| \geq 1$ and $|t| \geq 1$. Let us consider the vector

$$
s x \boxplus x \boxplus(1-\epsilon) y \boxplus t y
$$

where $\epsilon>0$ is sufficiently small. Clearly, since $s=-t$, we have $s \boxplus 1 \boxplus(1-\epsilon) \boxplus t=1 \boxplus(1-\epsilon)=1$.
If $i \in I$ then, since $s=-t$ and $x_{i}=y_{i}$, one has $s x_{i} \boxplus x_{i} \boxplus(1-\epsilon) y_{i} \boxplus t y_{i}=x_{i} \boxplus(1-\epsilon) y_{i}=x_{i}=y_{i}=z_{i}$.
If $i \notin I$ then, since $s x_{i} \neq-t x_{i},|s| \geq 1$ and $|t| \geq 1$, we have $s x_{i} \boxplus x_{i} \boxplus(1-\epsilon) y_{i} \boxplus t y_{i}=s x_{i} \boxplus t y_{i}=z_{i}$. We conclude that $z \in \mathcal{D}^{\infty}(x, y)$.
(c) $I \neq \emptyset$ and there is some $i_{0} \in I$, such that $x_{i_{0}} \neq y_{i_{0}}$. We first prove that in such a case we have $s \neq-t$. Suppose that this is not the case. We have $s x_{i_{0}} \boxplus t y_{i_{0}}=s x_{i_{0}} \boxplus(-s) y_{i_{0}}=0$. However this implies $x_{i_{0}}=y_{i_{0}}$ that is a contradiction. Moreover, from Lemma 4.1.2.(c) we have $\max \{|s|,|t|\}=1$ and $\max \{s, t\}=1$. Assume for example that $t=1$.

Suppose that $i \in I$. We have $t y_{i}=y_{i}=-s x_{i}$ and therefore

$$
s^{\left(p_{q}\right)} x_{i} \stackrel{p_{q}}{+} t^{\left(p_{q}\right)} y_{i}=s^{\left(p_{q}\right)} x_{i} \stackrel{p_{q}}{-} s t^{\left(p_{q}\right)} x_{i}=\left(s^{\left(p_{q}\right) \stackrel{p_{q}}{-}} s t^{\left(p_{q}\right)}\right) x_{i}
$$

By hypothesis $\lim _{k \longrightarrow \infty} z_{i}^{\left(p_{q}\right)}=z_{i}$. Hence the sequence $\left\{s^{\left(p_{q}\right) \stackrel{p_{q}}{-}} s t^{\left(p_{q}\right)}\right\}_{q \in \mathbb{N}}$ has a limit. Let us denote

$$
s^{\prime}=\lim _{q \longrightarrow \infty} s^{\left(p_{q}\right) \stackrel{p_{q}}{-}} s t^{\left(p_{q}\right)}
$$

By hypothesis we have $z_{i}=s^{\prime} x_{i}$. Note that, since

$$
\left|s^{\left(p_{q}\right) \stackrel{p_{q}}{-}} s t^{\left(p_{q}\right)}\right| \leq\left|s^{\left(p_{q}\right)}\right| \stackrel{p_{q}}{+}\left|s t^{\left(p_{q}\right)}\right|
$$

we have taking the limit $\left|s^{\prime}\right| \leq \max \{|s|, t|s|\} \leq|s|$. We consider two cases.
(i) Suppose that $s^{\prime} \neq-s$. Let us consider the vector

$$
s x \boxplus s^{\prime} x \boxplus 0 y \boxplus y
$$

If $i \in I$ then, since $s x_{i}=-y_{i}$, we have $w_{i}=s x_{i} \boxplus s^{\prime} x_{i} \boxplus 0 y_{i} \boxplus y_{i}=s^{\prime} x_{i}=z_{i}$.
If $i \notin I$, then since $s \neq-s^{\prime}$, we have either $s=s^{\prime}$ or $\left|s^{\prime}\right|<|s|$. Hence, $s x_{i} \boxplus s^{\prime} x_{i} \boxplus 0 y_{i} \boxplus y_{i}=s x_{i} \boxplus y_{i}=z_{i}$. It follows that $z=s x \boxplus s^{\prime} x \boxplus 0 y \boxplus y$. Moreover, since $-s \neq t=1$ and $\left|s^{\prime}\right| \leq|s|$, we have $s \boxplus s^{\prime} \boxplus 0 \boxplus 1=1$. Hence $z \in \mathcal{D}^{\infty}(x, y)$.
(ii) Suppose now that $s^{\prime}=-s$. Let us consider the vector

$$
s x \boxplus 0 x \boxplus y \boxplus y
$$

If $i \in I$ then, since $s x_{i}=-y_{i}$, we have $s x_{i} \boxplus 0 x_{i} \boxplus y_{i} \boxplus y_{i}=y_{i}$. However since $y_{i}=-s x_{i}$, we deduce that $y_{i}=s^{\prime} x_{i}=z_{i}$.

If $i \notin I$ then, $s x_{i} \neq-y_{i}$. Thus, we have $s x_{i} \boxplus 0 x_{i} \boxplus y_{i} \boxplus y_{i}=s x_{i} \boxplus y_{i}=z_{i}$. Hence, we conclude that $z=s x \boxplus 0 x \boxplus y \boxplus y$. Moreover, since $\max \{|s|,|t|\}=1, s \boxplus 0 \boxplus 1 \boxplus 1=1$.

Consequently, we have shown that $z \in\left\{t x \boxplus r x \boxplus s y \boxplus w y: t \boxplus r \boxplus s \boxplus w=1, t, r, s, w \in \mathbb{R}\right\}$. If $s=1$ the proof is symmetrical. Hence

$$
\underset{p \longrightarrow \infty}{\operatorname{La}} \mathcal{D}^{(p)}(x, y) \subset\left\{t x \boxplus r x \boxplus s y \boxplus w y: t \boxplus r \boxplus s \boxplus w=1, t, r, s, w \in \mathbb{R}\right\}
$$

In the next example, it is shown that the formalism described above allows us to define subsets of $\mathbb{R}^{n}$ that are unbounded.

Example 4.1.5 Suppose that $n=3$ and let us consider the points $x=(3,-2,1)$ and $y=(1,-1,1)$. Suppose that $t=1, r=\delta=-w$ and $s=0$ where $\delta$ is a real number. Clearly, $t \boxplus r \boxplus s \boxplus w=1 \boxplus \delta \boxplus(-\delta) \boxplus 0=1$. It follows that

$$
z_{\delta}:=t x \boxplus r x \boxplus s y \boxplus w y=t\left(\begin{array}{l}
3 \\
-2 \\
1
\end{array}\right) \boxplus \delta\left(\begin{array}{l}
3 \\
-2 \\
1
\end{array}\right) \boxplus(-\delta)\left(\begin{array}{l}
1 \\
-1 \\
1
\end{array}\right) \boxplus 0\left(\begin{array}{l}
1 \\
-1 \\
1
\end{array}\right)=\left(\begin{array}{c}
3 \delta \\
-2 \delta \\
1
\end{array}\right) \in \mathcal{D}^{\infty}(x, y)
$$

It follows that

$$
\lim _{|\delta| \longrightarrow \infty}\left\|z_{\delta}\right\|=+\infty
$$

In the following it is shown that $\mathcal{D}^{\infty}(x, y)$ is path connected.
Proposition 4.1.6 Let $x, y \in \mathbb{R}^{n}$ and suppose that $x \neq y$. Then $\mathcal{D}^{\infty}(x, y)$ is path-connected.
Proof: Suppose that $u, v \in \mathcal{D}^{\infty}(x, y)$ with $u \neq v$. Then, there exists a sequence $\left\{\left(u^{(p)}, v^{(p)}\right)\right\}_{p \in \mathbb{N}}$ such that for all $p \in \mathbb{N}\left(u^{(p)}, v^{(p)}\right) \in \mathcal{D}^{(p)}(x, y) \times \mathcal{D}^{(p)}(x, y)$ and $\lim _{p \longrightarrow \infty}\left(u^{(p)}, v^{(p)}\right)=(u, v)$. Let $\mathcal{I}(u, v)=$ $\left\{i \in[n]: u_{i} v_{i}<0\right\}$. Since $\lim _{p \longrightarrow \infty}\left(u^{(p)}, v^{(p)}\right)=(u, v)$, there is some $p_{0} \in \mathbb{N}$ such that for all $p \geq p_{0}$, $\mathcal{I}(u, v)=\mathcal{I}\left(u^{(p)}, v^{(p)}\right)$. For all $i \in \mathcal{I}(u, v)$ and all $p \geq p_{0}$, there is a unique point $\gamma_{i}^{(p)} \in C o^{p}(x, y)$ such that $\left\{\gamma_{i}^{(p)}\right\}=H_{i} \cap \mathcal{D}^{(p)}(x, y)$ where, for all $i \in[n], H_{i}=\left\{x \in \mathbb{R}^{n}: x_{i}=0\right\}$. For all $i \in \mathcal{I}(u, v)$,

$$
\operatorname{Ls}_{p \longrightarrow \infty}\left(H_{i} \cap \mathcal{D}^{(p)}(x, y)\right) \subset H_{i} \cap \mathcal{D}^{\infty}(x, y)
$$

that is a nonempty subset of $\mathcal{D}^{\infty}(x, y)$. Let $\gamma_{i} \in \operatorname{Ls}_{p \longrightarrow \infty}\left(H_{i} \cap \mathcal{D}^{(p)}(x, y)\right)$. This implies that there is an increasing sequence $\left\{p_{q}\right\}$ such that

$$
\lim _{q \longrightarrow \infty} \gamma_{i}^{\left(p_{q}\right)}=\gamma_{i} \in H_{i} \cap \mathcal{D}^{\infty}(x, y)
$$

Let us denote $n(u, v)=\operatorname{Card} \mathcal{I}(u, v)$. For all $p \geq p_{0}$ one can find a sequence $\left\{i_{k}\right\}_{k \in[n(u, v)-1]}$ such that

$$
\gamma_{i_{k}}^{\left(p_{q}\right)} \cdot \gamma_{i_{k+1}}^{\left(p_{q}\right)} \geq 0
$$

It follows that

$$
\operatorname{Lim}_{q \longrightarrow \infty} C o^{p_{q}}\left(\gamma_{i_{k}}^{\left(p_{q}\right)}, \gamma_{i_{k+1}}^{\left(p_{q}\right)}\right)=C o^{\infty}\left(\gamma_{i_{k}}, \gamma_{i_{k+1}}\right)
$$

However,

$$
\begin{aligned}
\operatorname{La}_{p \longrightarrow \infty} C o^{p}\left(u^{(p)}, v^{(p)}\right) & =\bigcup_{k \in[u(u, v)-1]} \operatorname{La}_{q \longrightarrow \infty} C o^{p_{q}}\left(\gamma_{i_{k}}^{(p_{q})}, \gamma_{i_{k+1}}^{(p_{q})}\right) \\
& =\bigcup_{k \in[u(u, v)-1]} \operatorname{Lim}_{q \longrightarrow \infty} C o^{p_{q}}\left(\gamma_{i_{k}}^{(p_{q})}, \gamma_{i_{k+1}}^{(p_{q})}\right) \\
& =\bigcup_{k \in[u(u, v)-1]} C o^{\infty}\left(\gamma_{i_{k}}, \gamma_{i_{k+1}}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

Now, since any set $C o^{\infty}\left(\gamma_{i_{k}}, \gamma_{i_{k+1}}\right)$ is path-connected, it follows that there exists a continuous map $\psi$ : $[0,1] \longrightarrow \mathcal{D}^{\infty}(x, y)$ such that $\psi(0)=u$ and $\psi(1)=v$.

Corollary 4.1.7 For all $x, y \in \mathbb{R}^{n}$ with $x \neq y$,

$$
C o^{\infty}(x, y) \subset \mathcal{D}^{\infty}(x, y)
$$

Proof: From $[8]$

$$
C o^{\infty}(x, y):=\left\{t x \boxplus r x \boxplus s y \boxplus w y: t \boxplus r \boxplus s \boxplus w=1, t, r, s, w \in \mathbb{R}_{+}\right\}
$$

The result is then immediate, since $C o^{\infty}(x, y)$ is the set of all the $\mathbb{B}$-convex combinations such that $t, r, s, w \geq$ 0 .

Corollary 4.1.7 does not imply that $\mathcal{D}^{\infty}$ is idempotent symmetric convex. In general, this is not true. This can be seen in Figure 10, where $x \boxminus y$ and $y \boxminus x$ belong to $\mathcal{D}^{\infty}(x, y)$. However, $(x \boxminus y) \boxplus(y \boxminus x)=0 \notin \mathcal{D}^{\infty}(x, y)$.

Proposition 4.1.8 Let $Y$ be an idempotent symmetric subspace of $\mathbb{R}^{n}$. Then, for all $x, y \in \mathbb{R}^{n}$ with $x \neq y$ we have $\mathcal{D}^{\infty}(x, y) \subset Y$.

Proof: We have shown that

$$
\mathcal{D}^{\infty}(x, y)=\{t x \boxplus r x \boxplus s y \boxplus w y: t \boxplus r \boxplus s \boxplus w=1, t, r, s, w \in \mathbb{R}\}
$$

From Proposition 2.1.14 the result is then immediate.
Notice that since $\left(\mathbb{R}^{n}, \boxplus, \cdot\right)$ and $\left(\widetilde{\mathbb{M}}^{n}, \widetilde{\boxplus}, \otimes\right)$ are isomorphic one can deduce the algebraic form of a line passing trough $z$ and $u$. The multiplicative neutral element of $\cdot$ is replaced with $0=1_{\widetilde{\mathbb{M}}}$ and we have

$$
\widetilde{\mathcal{D}}^{\infty}(z, u)=\left\{t z \boxplus r z \boxplus s u \boxplus w u: t \boxplus r \boxplus s \boxplus w=0, t, r, s, w \in \widetilde{\mathbb{M}}\right\}
$$

# 4.2 Half-Lines and Inclusion Properties 

In the next statement, it is shown that, for all $x, y \in \mathbb{R}^{n}$ with $x \neq y$, the line $\mathcal{D}^{\infty}(x, y)$ contains two half lines spanned from two specific points. $\mathcal{D}^{\infty}(x, y)$ is called the $I$-line spanned by $x$ and $y$.

Proposition 4.2.1 Let $x, y \in \mathbb{R}^{n}$ and suppose that $x \neq y$. Let $I=\left\{i \in[n]: x_{i} \neq y_{i}\right\}$ and $J=[n] \backslash I$. We have the following inclusions:
(a) If $J=\emptyset$ then

$$
\{t(y \boxminus x): t \in[1, \infty[\} \subset \mathcal{D}^{\infty}(x, y) \quad \text { and } \quad\{t(x \boxminus y): t \in[1, \infty[\} \subset \mathcal{D}^{\infty}(x, y)
$$

(b) If $J \neq \emptyset$ then

$$
x_{[J]}+\{t(y \boxminus x): t \in[1, \infty[\} \subset \mathcal{D}^{\infty}(x, y) \quad \text { and } \quad x_{[J]}+\{t(x \boxminus y): t \in[1, \infty[\} \subset \mathcal{D}^{\infty}(x, y)
$$

where $x_{[J]}=\sum_{k \in J} x_{k} e_{k}=\sum_{k \in J} y_{k} e_{k}=y_{[J]}$.
Proof: (a) We first note that since $J=\emptyset$ and $I=[n]$

$$
x \boxminus y=x \boxplus x \boxplus 0 y \boxplus(-y) \in\{t x \boxplus r x \boxplus s y \boxplus w y: t \boxplus r \boxplus s \boxplus w=1, t, r, s, w \in \mathbb{R}\}
$$

For all $t \geq 1$, let us consider the vector

$$
z=t x \boxplus(-t) y
$$

Since $t \geq 1$, we have

$$
z=t x \boxplus x \boxplus 0 y \boxplus(-t) y
$$

Moreover $t \boxplus 1 \boxplus 0 \boxplus(-t)=1$. Clearly $z \in\{t x \boxplus r x \boxplus s y \boxplus w y: t \boxplus r \boxplus s \boxplus w=1, t, r, s, w \in \mathbb{R}\}$, which proves the first part of (a). The proof of the second part is symmetrical swapping $x$ and $y$. (b) Let us denote $\mathbb{R}_{[I]}=\left\{\sum_{k \in I} x_{k} e_{k}: x \in \mathbb{R}^{n}\right\}$. By hypothesis $x, y \in x_{[J]}+\mathbb{R}_{[I]}$. Hence $\mathcal{D}^{\infty}(x, y) \subset x_{[J]}+\mathbb{R}_{[I]}$. Let $n_{I}=\operatorname{Card}(I)$ and let $\mathcal{D}_{[I]}^{\infty}(x, y)$ be the canonical decomposition of $\mathcal{D}^{\infty}(x, y)$ over $\mathbb{R}_{[I]}$. By definition for all $i \in I$ we have $x_{i} \neq y_{i}$. Since $\mathbb{R}_{[I]}$ is isomorphic to its restriction projection onto $\mathbb{R}^{n_{I}}$ we deduce from (a) that

$$
\left\{t\left(x_{[I]} \boxminus y_{[I]}\right): t \in[1, \infty[\} \subset \mathcal{D}_{[I]}^{\infty}(x, y)\right.
$$

However $\mathcal{D}^{\infty}(x, y)=x_{[J]}+\mathcal{D}_{[I]}^{\infty}(x, y)$. Moreover $x_{[J]} \boxminus y_{[J]}=0$. Hence

$$
\begin{aligned}
x_{[J]}+\{t(x \boxminus y): t \in[1, \infty[ \} & =x_{[J]}+\left\{t\left(x_{[I]} \boxminus y_{[I]}\right): t \in[1, \infty[ \}\right. \\
& \subset x_{[J]}+\mathcal{D}_{[I]}^{\infty}(x, y) \\
& \subset \mathcal{D}^{\infty}(x, y)
\end{aligned}
$$

The proof of the second part of the statement is symmetrical.
Notice that Proposition 4.2.1.(b) can be deduced from Proposition 4.2.1.(a) by considering the canonical isomorphism $\psi_{I}$ defined from the set $\left\{z \in \mathbb{R}^{n}: z_{j}=0, j \notin I\right\}$ to $\mathbb{R}^{m}$ where $m=\operatorname{Card}(I)$.
![img-10.jpeg](img-10.jpeg)

Fig. 11: Inclusion of half-lines.
Let $x, y \in \mathbb{R}^{n}$. The half lines $\mathcal{D}_{+}(x, y)=\{t(x \boxminus y): t \in[1, \infty[ \}$ and $\mathcal{D}_{-}(x, y)=\{t(y \boxminus x): t \in[1, \infty[ \}$ are respectively called the upper and lower half-lines components of the $I$-line $\mathcal{D}^{\infty}(x, y)$.

Example 4.2.2 Let us consider the case proposed in 4.1.5 with $x=(3,-2,1)$ and $y=(1,-1,1)$. In such a case $I=\{1,2\}$ and $J=\{3\}$. We have:

$$
x \boxminus y=\left(\begin{array}{c}
3 \\
-2 \\
1
\end{array}\right) \boxminus\left(\begin{array}{c}
1 \\
-1 \\
1
\end{array}\right)=\left(\begin{array}{c}
3 \\
-2 \\
0
\end{array}\right)
$$

and

$$
x_{\{3\}}=y_{\{3\}}=\left(\begin{array}{l}
0 \\
0 \\
1
\end{array}\right)
$$

It follows that

$$
D^{\infty}(x, y) \supset\left(\begin{array}{l}
0 \\
0 \\
1
\end{array}\right)+\left\{t\left(\begin{array}{c}
3 \\
-2 \\
0
\end{array}\right), t \in \mathbb{R}\right\}=\left\{\left(\begin{array}{c}
3 t \\
-2 t \\
1
\end{array}\right): t \in \mathbb{R}\right\}=\mathcal{D}_{+}(x, y)
$$

and

$$
D^{\infty}(x, y) \supset\left(\begin{array}{l}
0 \\
0 \\
1
\end{array}\right)+\left\{t\left(\begin{array}{c}
-3 \\
2 \\
0
\end{array}\right), t \in \mathbb{R}\right\}=\left\{\left(\begin{array}{c}
-3 t \\
2 t \\
1
\end{array}\right): t \in \mathbb{R}\right\}=\mathcal{D}_{-}(x, y)
$$

# 4.3 Parallel Lines 

From Proposition 4.2.1, any $\digamma$-lines contains two half-lines components. Let $\mathcal{D}^{\infty}(x, y)$ and $\mathcal{E}^{\infty}(u, v)$ be two $\digamma$-lines respectively spanned from $x$ and $y$ and $u$ and $v$. We say that $\mathcal{E}^{\infty}(u, v)$ and $\mathcal{D}^{\infty}(x, y)$ are $\digamma$ parallel if $x \boxminus y \propto u \boxminus v$. Equivalently, this means that $x \boxminus y$ and $u \boxminus v$ are collinear, that is there is some $\alpha \in \mathbb{R} \backslash\{0\}$ such that $(x \boxminus y)=\alpha(u \boxminus v)$. From Proposition 4.2.1, there exist two half lines components $\mathcal{E}_{-}(u, v)$ and $\mathcal{E}_{+}(u, v)$ of $\mathcal{E}^{\infty}(u, v)$ and two half lines components $\mathcal{D}_{-}(x, y)$ and $\mathcal{D}_{+}(x, y)$ of $\mathcal{D}^{\infty}(x, y)$ such that $\mathcal{E}_{+}(u, v) \supset(\subset) \mathcal{D}_{+}(x, y)$ and $\mathcal{E}_{-}(u, v) \supset(\subset) \mathcal{D}_{-}(x, y)$.
![img-11.jpeg](img-11.jpeg)

Fig. 12: Parallel $\digamma$-lines.
Figure 12 depicts the case of two parallel lines. In Figure 13, we consider the case of two secant lines.
![img-12.jpeg](img-12.jpeg)

Fig. 13: Secant $\digamma$-lines.
Traditional axioms of planar Euclidean geometry postulate that: $\left(a_{1}\right)$ a straight line may be drawn between any two points; $\left(a_{2}\right)$ any terminated straight line may be extended indefinitely; $\left(a_{3}\right)$ a circle may be drawn with any given point as center and any given radius, $\left(a_{4}\right)$ all right angles are equal; $(v)$ for any given point not on a given line, there is exactly one line through the point that does not meet the given line.

It is well known that the fifth axiom does not follow from the first four. Clearly, the geometric implications of the algebraic structure proposed in this paper do not conflict with the first 4 axioms. Not surprisingly, this is not the case for the fifth. In particular:
(i) two distinct parallel lines may have an infinity of common points (Figure 12);
(ii) there may exist an infinity of $\digamma$-lines passing by two distinct points $x$ and $y$ (Figure 12);
(iii) two secant lines may have an infinity of common points (Figure 13);
(iv) a $\digamma$-line may not be spanned by two distinct points it contains (Figure 13).

In the following a system of inequations characterizing a $\digamma$-line that passes from two distinct points is provided. This we do by considering the suitable notion of determinant introduced in [10]. The next intermediary result establishes an algebraic description of the limit of a sequence of $\varphi_{p}$-hyperplanes. The next result was established in [11].

Proposition 4.3.1 Let $V$ be the $n \times n$ matrix with $v_{i}$ as $i$-th column for each $i$. Let $V_{(i)}$ be the matrix obtained from $V$ by replacing line $i$ with the transpose of the unit vector $\mathbb{1}_{n}$. Suppose that $|V|_{\infty} \neq 0$. Let $\left\{H_{p}(V)\right\}_{p \in \mathbb{N}}$ be the sequence of $\varphi_{p}$-hyperplanes passing trough each point $v_{i}$. Then

$$
\operatorname{Lim}_{p \longrightarrow \infty} H_{p}(V)=\left\{x \in \mathbb{R}^{n}: \underset{i \in[n]}{\sim}\left|V_{(i)}\right|_{\infty} x_{i} \leq|V|_{\infty} \leq \underset{i \in[n]}{\sim}\left|V_{(i)}\right|_{\infty} x_{i}\right\}
$$

Given two distinct points $x, y \in \mathbb{R}^{2}$, any point $z \in \mathcal{D}(x, y)$ satisfies the relation:

$$
|z-x, z-y|=\left|\begin{array}{ll}
z_{1}-x_{1} & z_{1}-y_{1} \\
z_{2}-x_{2} & z_{2}-y_{2}
\end{array}\right|=0
$$

Equivalently, we have

$$
\left(x_{2}-y_{2}\right) z_{1}+\left(y_{1}-x_{1}\right) z_{2}=|x, y|
$$

The following proposition establishes an analogous result in the case of the $\digamma$-line $\mathcal{D}^{\infty}$. This algebraic characterization is an immediate consequence of Proposition 4.3.1 (see [11]). Let $x, y \in \mathbb{R}^{2}$ with $x \neq y$. Then:

$$
\mathcal{D}^{\infty}(x, y)=\left\{z \in \mathbb{R}^{2}:\left(x_{2} \boxminus y_{2}\right) z_{1} \frown\left(y_{1} \boxminus x_{1}\right) z_{2} \leq|x, y|_{\infty} \leq\left(x_{2} \boxminus y_{2}\right) z_{1} \uparrow\left(y_{1} \boxminus x_{1}\right) z_{2}\right\}
$$

In the following, we show that the equations of two parallel lines in the plane obey algebraic rules analogous to those of the linear case.

Lemma 4.3.2 Let $\mathcal{D}^{\infty}$ and $\mathcal{E}^{\infty}$ be two parallel $\digamma$-lines of $\mathbb{R}^{2}$. Then there exists $a \in \mathbb{R}^{2}, c, d \in \mathbb{R}$ such that:

$$
\mathcal{D}^{\infty}=\left\{z \in \mathbb{R}^{2}:\langle a, z\rangle_{\infty}^{-} \leq c \leq\langle a, z\rangle_{\infty}^{+} \leq c\right\}
$$

and

$$
\mathcal{E}^{\infty}=\left\{z \in \mathbb{R}^{2}:\langle a, z\rangle_{\infty}^{-} \leq d \leq\langle a, z\rangle_{\infty}^{+} \leq c\right\}
$$

Proof: Suppose now that $\mathcal{D}^{\infty}$ and $\mathcal{E}^{\infty}$ are two $\digamma$-line respectively spanned from $x, y$ and $u, v$, where $x, y, u, v \in \mathbb{R}^{2}$. By definition we have:

$$
\mathcal{E}^{\infty}=\left\{z \in \mathbb{R}^{2}:\left(u_{2} \boxminus v_{2}\right) z_{1} \frown\left(v_{1} \boxminus u_{1}\right) z_{2} \leq|u, v|_{\infty} \leq\left(u_{2} \boxminus v_{2}\right) z_{1} \uparrow\left(v_{1} \boxminus u_{1}\right) z_{2}\right\}
$$

If $\mathcal{D}^{\infty}$ and $\mathcal{E}^{\infty}$ are parallel then $(u \boxminus v) \propto(x \boxminus y)$. Therefore, there is a real number $\alpha \neq 0$ such that $(u \boxminus v)=\alpha(x \boxminus y)$. Hence:

$$
\mathcal{E}^{\infty}=\left\{z \in \mathbb{R}^{2}: \alpha\left(x_{2} \boxminus y_{2}\right) z_{1} \frown \alpha\left(y_{1} \boxminus x_{1}\right) z_{2} \leq|u, v|_{\infty} \leq \alpha\left(x_{2} \boxminus y_{2}\right) z_{1} \uparrow \alpha\left(y_{1} \boxminus x_{1}\right) z_{2}\right\}
$$

Suppose that $\alpha>0$, then:

$$
\mathcal{E}^{\infty}=\left\{z \in \mathbb{R}^{2}:\left(x_{2} \boxminus y_{2}\right) z_{1} \frown\left(y_{1} \boxminus x_{1}\right) z_{2} \leq \alpha^{-1}|u, v|_{\infty} \leq\left(x_{2} \boxminus y_{2}\right) z_{1} \uparrow\left(y_{1} \boxminus x_{1}\right) z_{2}\right\}
$$

We deduce the result taking $a=x \boxminus y, c=|x, y|_{\infty}$, and $d=\alpha^{-1}|u, v|_{\infty}$. If $\alpha<0$, then:

$$
\mathcal{E}^{\infty}=\left\{z \in \mathbb{R}^{2}:\left(x_{2} \boxminus y_{2}\right) z_{1} \frown\left(y_{1} \boxminus x_{1}\right) z_{2} \geq \alpha^{-1}|u, v|_{\infty} \geq\left(x_{2} \boxminus y_{2}\right) z_{1} \uparrow\left(y_{1} \boxminus x_{1}\right) z_{2}\right\}
$$

Since $\left(x_{2} \boxminus y_{2}\right) z_{1} \frown\left(y_{1} \boxminus x_{1}\right)=-\left(\left(y_{2} \boxminus x_{2}\right) z_{1} \uparrow\left(x_{1} \boxminus y_{1}\right)\right)$ and $\left(x_{2} \boxminus y_{2}\right) z_{1} \uparrow\left(y_{1} \boxminus x_{1}\right)=-\left(\left(y_{2} \boxminus x_{2}\right) z_{1} \frown\right.$ $\left.\left(x_{1} \boxminus y_{1}\right)\right)$ we deduce that:

$$
\mathcal{E}^{\infty}=\left\{z \in \mathbb{R}^{2}:\left(y_{2} \boxminus x_{2}\right) z_{1} \frown\left(x_{1} \boxminus y_{1}\right) z_{2} \leq|\alpha|^{-1}|u, v|_{\infty} \leq\left(y_{2} \boxminus x_{2}\right) z_{1} \uparrow\left(x_{1} \boxminus y_{1}\right) z_{2}\right\}
$$

Now note that, since $\mathcal{D}^{\infty}(x, y)=\mathcal{D}^{\infty}(y, x)$, we also have

$$
\mathcal{D}^{\infty}=\left\{z \in \mathbb{R}^{2}:\left(y_{2} \boxminus x_{2}\right) z_{1} \stackrel{\rightharpoonup}{\rightharpoonup}\left(x_{1} \boxminus y_{1}\right) z_{2} \leq|y, x|_{\infty} \leq\left(y_{2} \boxminus x_{2}\right) z_{1} \stackrel{+}{\rightharpoonup}\left(x_{1} \boxminus y_{1}\right) z_{2}\right\}
$$

Hence, taking $a=y \boxminus x, c=|y, x|_{\infty}$ and $d=|\alpha|^{-1}|u, v|_{\infty}$ yields the result.

Example 4.3.3 Suppose that $x=(3,1), y=(1,-2), u=(-2,4)$ and $v=(-6,1)$. We have:

$$
x \boxminus y=\binom{3 \boxminus 1}{1 \boxplus(-2)}=\binom{3}{2} \quad \text { and } \quad u \boxminus v=\binom{-2 \boxplus(-6)}{4 \boxminus 1}=\binom{6}{4}
$$

It follows that $u \boxminus v=2(x \boxplus y)$. Moreover,

$$
|x, y|_{\infty}=3 \cdot(-2) \boxminus 1 \cdot 1=-6 \quad \text { and } \quad|u, v|_{\infty}=(-2) \cdot 1 \boxplus(-6) \cdot 4=24
$$

Therefore:

$$
\mathcal{D}^{\infty}(x, y)=\left\{z \in \mathbb{R}^{2}:\left(1 \boxplus(-2)\right) z_{1} \stackrel{\rightharpoonup}{\rightharpoonup}(1 \boxminus 3) z_{2} \leq-6 \leq\left(1 \boxplus(-2)\right) z_{1} \stackrel{+}{\rightharpoonup}(1 \boxminus 3) z_{2}\right\}
$$

Hence:

$$
\mathcal{D}^{\infty}(x, y)=\left\{z \in \mathbb{R}^{2}: 2 z_{1} \stackrel{\rightharpoonup}{\rightharpoonup}(-3) z_{2} \leq-6 \leq 2 z_{1} \stackrel{+}{\rightharpoonup}(-3) z_{2}\right\}
$$

In addition we have:

$$
\mathcal{D}^{\infty}(u, v)=\left\{z \in \mathbb{R}^{2}:(4 \boxplus(-1)) z_{1} \stackrel{\rightharpoonup}{\rightharpoonup}((-6) \boxplus(-2)) z_{2} \leq-6 \leq(4 \boxplus(-1)) z_{1} \stackrel{+}{\rightharpoonup}((-6) \boxplus(-2)) z_{2}\right\}
$$

Hence:

$$
\mathcal{D}^{\infty}(u, v)=\left\{z \in \mathbb{R}^{2}:(-4) z_{1} \stackrel{\rightharpoonup}{\rightharpoonup} 6 z_{2} \leq 24 \leq(-4) z_{1} \stackrel{+}{\rightharpoonup} 6 z_{2}\right\}
$$

Equivalently, by changing the sign and simplifying by 2:

$$
\mathcal{D}^{\infty}(u, v)=\left\{z \in \mathbb{R}^{2}: 2 z_{1} \stackrel{\rightharpoonup}{\rightharpoonup}(-3) z_{2} \leq-12 \leq 2 z_{1} \stackrel{+}{\rightharpoonup}(-3) z_{2}\right\}
$$

We can notice that the coefficients multiplying $z_{1}$ and $z_{2}$ are the same the difference relating only to the constant term.

# Conclusion 

In this article, we have explored certain geometric properties emerging from the deformation of a vector space structure defined over a scalar field. In particular, we have focused on notions of lines that can be seen as special limits of linear varieties. For future research, it would be valuable to investigate the connections between these notions and those typically derived from Max-Plus algebras, which are traditionally used in the formalism of tropical mathematics, as initiated in [29] and [27].

Compliance with Ethical Standards: Not applicable.
Data Availability Statement (DAS): No new data were created or analyzed in this study. Data sharing is not applicable to this article.

abstract:
This article analyzes the geometric properties of an idempotent,
non-associative algebraic structure that extends the Max-Times semiring. This
algebraic structure is useful for studying systems of Max-Times and Max-Plus
equations, employing an appropriate notion of a non-associative determinant. We
consider a connected ultrametric distance and demonstrate that it implies,
among other properties, an analogue of the Pythagorean relation. To this end,
we introduce a suitable notion of a right angle between two vectors and
investigate a trigonometric concept associated with the Chebyshev unit ball.
Following this approach, we explore the potential implications of these
properties in the complex plane.
  We provide an algebraic definition of a line passing through two points,
which corresponds to the Painlev\'e-Peano-Kuratowski limit of a sequence of
generalized lines. We establish that this definition leads to distinctive
geometric properties; in particular, two distinct parallel lines may share an
infinite number of points.
